<div class="hero-section"> <div class="hero-inner"> <div class="hero-kicker">P8105 Final Project · Columbia Public Health</div> <div class="hero-title">High-Cost Patients in U.S. Healthcare: Evidence from MEPS 2023</div> <div class="hero-subtitle"> Using the 2023 Medical Expenditure Panel Survey (MEPS), we replicate and extend Mitchell (2023) to study how healthcare spending is concentrated, who the high-cost patients are, which conditions drive spending, and how costs are distributed across services and payers. </div> <div class="hero-buttons"> <a href="project.html" class="hero-btn-primary"> <i class="fa-solid fa-chart-line"></i> Explore code & results </a> <a href="proposal.html" class="hero-btn-ghost"> <i class="fa-regular fa-file-lines"></i> Read project proposal </a> </div> </div> </div>


<div class="stats-strip"><div class="stats-top-row"><div class="stats-card"><div class="stats-card-label"><i class="fa-solid fa-bullseye"></i> FOCUS</div><div class="stats-card-text">High-cost patients, healthcare utilization, and value-based care in the U.S. system.</div></div><div class="stats-card"><div class="stats-card-label"><i class="fa-solid fa-database"></i> DATA</div><div class="stats-card-text">2023 MEPS (HC-251 &amp; HC-249) with person-level costs, conditions, and survey design features.</div></div><div class="stats-card"><div class="stats-card-label"><i class="fa-solid fa-gears"></i> METHODS</div><div class="stats-card-text">Reproducible R workflows, regression modeling, and interactive reporting for technical and non-technical stakeholders.</div></div></div><div class="stats-bottom-row"><div class="stats-pill"><div class="stats-pill-label">Sample size</div><div class="stats-pill-value">&asymp; 18,500 individuals</div></div><div class="stats-pill"><div class="stats-pill-label">Study year</div><div class="stats-pill-value">MEPS 2023</div></div><div class="stats-pill"><div class="stats-pill-label">Cost segments</div><div class="stats-pill-value">Top 1% · 5% · 10%</div></div></div></div>
<div class="section-heading">Project overview</div><div class="section-subtitle">This page summarizes the key elements of our study. For full details, please use the navigation bar or the buttons below.</div><div class="highlight-section"><div class="highlight-title">Key findings at a glance</div><div class="highlight-subtitle">We summarize three headline insights from our analysis of 2023 MEPS high-cost patients.</div><div class="highlight-grid"><div class="highlight-card"><div class="highlight-tag">Concentration</div><div class="highlight-main">Spending is concentrated in high-cost groups</div><div class="highlight-detail">Expenditures are extremely concentrated: a small group of “hot spotters” accounts for a disproportionate share of total costs.</div></div><div class="highlight-card"><div class="highlight-tag">Who are they?</div><div class="highlight-main">Older &amp; multi-morbid</div><div class="highlight-detail">High-cost patients are disproportionately adults aged 45+ with multiple CCSR conditions across cardiovascular, endocrine, and mental health domains.</div></div><div class="highlight-card"><div class="highlight-tag">Prediction</div><div class="highlight-main">Simple models go a long way</div><div class="highlight-detail">Age and a simple multimorbidity count explain most of the predictive signal; adding many diagnosis indicators only modestly improves accuracy.</div></div></div></div><div class="workflow-section"><div class="section-heading">Study workflow</div><ul class="workflow-list"><li class="workflow-step"><div class="workflow-number">1</div><div class="workflow-text">Import and clean 2023 MEPS person-level (HC-251) and condition-level (HC-249) files, harmonizing missing values and survey design variables.</div></li><li class="workflow-step"><div class="workflow-number">2</div><div class="workflow-text">Define expenditure groups (Bottom 50%, 50–90%, Top 10%, Top 5%, Top 1%) using survey-weighted quantiles of total expenditures (TOTEXP23).</div></li><li class="workflow-step"><div class="workflow-number">3</div><div class="workflow-text">Describe demographics, income/poverty, insurance, and clinical conditions across cost groups, and fit regression models to predict high-cost status.</div></li><li class="workflow-step"><div class="workflow-number">4</div><div class="workflow-text">Build an interactive Shiny dashboard to allow users to explore expenditure patterns by age, sex, race/ethnicity, income, and insurance coverage.</div></li></ul></div>


<div class="info-grid"> <div class="info-card"> <div class="info-card-title"> <i class="fa-solid fa-hospital-user info-card-icon"></i> High-cost patients </div> <div class="info-card-text">  We define high-cost expenditure groups (Top 1%, 5%, 10%, Bottom 50%) using survey-weighted percentiles of total annual expenditures (TOTEXP23) under the MEPS design. We then compare age, sex, race/ethnicity, income, and insurance coverage across these groups to characterize who appears in each segment.</div> </div> <div class="info-card"> <div class="info-card-title"> <i class="fa-solid fa-heart-pulse info-card-icon"></i> Conditions & disease burden </div> <div class="info-card-text"> Using the 2023 Medical Conditions file (HC-249) and CCSR codes, we summarize diagnoses at the person level and construct a simple multimorbidity count. We then examine how key condition groups and disease burden vary across expenditure groups, focusing on high-cost patients.</div> </div> <div class="info-card"> <div class="info-card-title"> <i class="fa-solid fa-notes-medical info-card-icon"></i> Services, payers & dashboards </div> <div class="info-card-text"> We decompose annual spending by service type (inpatient, outpatient, ER, prescriptions, home health) and by payer (out-of-pocket, private insurance, Medicare, Medicaid) to highlight where money is being spent. These summaries feed into an interactive <code>shiny</code> dashboard that allows users to explore expenditure patterns by demographic and insurance profiles.</div> </div> </div>
